Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as an attempt to legitimize government censorship that occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The proposal is viewed as a means for the government to control what people see, hear, or read, infringing on freedom of speech.
There is a lack of clarity in defining 'misinformation' and 'disinformation', leading to potential confusion and misuse.
The legislation could lead to abuse of power by the government and digital platforms.
Excluding media and government from the legislation is seen as unfair and indicative of potential bias.
The proposal is perceived as a step backward to a more censored society, reminiscent of past censorship practices in Australia.
Notable Quotes: This proposed legislation appears to be an attempt to legitimise the censorship of Australians that the Government covertly carried out during the Covid drama.
Misinformation cannot be legislated against for the very reason it goes against freedom of speech; our democratic right to access and share information, thoughts, ideas.
If this legislation goes ahead, the media cannot be excluded.
This proposed legislation is a step backwards to where the government wants to regain control of what a person, hears, views or reads but on their terms not on a community standards test.
